I started the home loan process with BOV 35 weeks ago, and to this [SURNAME], I still do not have a confirmed date for the final deed.
There have been no delays on my end, as this is not my first property‚ÄîI'm fully familiar with the procedures and paperwork involved.

The notary's file was submitted in November, and yet, according to the latest email I received last week, the file is somehow still stuck in the pre-vetting stage which makes no sense because I had received an official email from BOV on the 19th of December, stating that the assessment was finalized and everything was in order.
The next step, according to the email, was that the legal office would contact my notary with a date.
Emails and phone calls have been of no help.
Every time I reach out, I am passed from one person to another, and all I hear is "someone is working on it" or "you have to [SURNAME].
" I understand that processes need to be followed, but these [SURNAME] delays are completely unacceptable.
This ongoing delay is putting me at risk of losing the entire property.
On top of that, all the extra costs for extension letters are falling on me as the client.

If the promise of sale falls through, I [NAME] be left with notary costs, bank fees, architect fees, and the life and home insurances which I have been paying from October 2024 when the BOV employee that was taking care of my loan process told me to apply and start them.
Not to mention, I'll have to start searching for another property in a market where prices have already risen.
It's incredibly disappointing to see Bank of [SURNAME] advertise about having the best home rates, only to fail in delivering timely service and proper support for their clients.
This situation has become beyond frustrating now.

Terrible Experience with Interni Italia by Attaguile ‚Äì Avoid at All Costs Detailed Review: We really regret going with Interni and making the trip all the way to Sicily, hoping to get quality furniture.
Save yourself the hassle and money‚Äîthere are way better companies in Malta you can go with instead.
We trusted the recommendations from family and friends who had used them before, but this was NOT the same company they described.
The dining table we ordered barely had [SURNAME] info in the brochure, so we relied heavily on their supposed "expertise.
" They kept reassuring us they knew their products inside and out.
Well, they didn't.
The colour of the dining table changed twice‚Äîonce when we made the final payment (which we reluctantly accepted because we didn't want to lose the deposit), and again upon delivery.
The table we got in the end was nothing like what was promised.
All this while communicating in fluent Italian as English is very poorly spoken at Interni.
On top of that, the workers they sent were rude, unprofessional, and even damaged our gypsum ceiling during installation without bothering to tell us.
To make matters worse, they admitted that the designer who worked on our project doesn't even work with the company anymore (which says a lot).
We were also told that they had received negative feedback about one of the installers that they sent to our house‚Äîand yet, they still continued contracting him to their clients.
After weeks of back-and-forth to discuss the issue of the dining table, Interni were dodging us, offering nothing but a fruitless video call.
We even reached out to the owner and told him we'd be going public with this nightmare.
Interni's Response: The owner challenged us to pursue legal action and accused us of trying to "blackmail" him with a negative review.
He claimed to also have advised his lawyer of the same.
(We didn't even bother replying to that ridiculous written message.
The next morning, the owner kept trying to contact us, asking for an in-person meeting.
) We finally met with one of their Interior Design Consultants, who basically claimed they had delivered what we ordered, and couldn't care less that we were misled by two of their designers.
During the meeting we explained that the designer could have provided samples of the dining table's color but didn't, and that critically, the table we received didn't match the brochure description.
In the end, their only offer was a measly ‚Ç¨200 for the inconvenience caused by the installers.
Presently, this case is being investigated by the European Consumer Centre as the Malta consumer affairs Authority has no jurisdiction over Interni since its an Italian registered company.
This makes it harder for you to conclude cases.
So beware.
Bottom line: Stay away from Interni if you care about quality service or professionalism.
In hindsight, we trusted that Interni would take care of us far too much, which was a mistake.
However, being given a table that is different from the brochure was completely beyond our control and entirely their fault.
We have since done business with Styles Furniture in St. Venera and had a very positive experience.
Many says that [NAME] customer care is sh*t... but I was served really really well and with customer service efficiently at [NAME] [NAME] by a representer named [NAME].
Very well done so I give her praise cause we usually get it better to share negative feedback rather than the positive feedback.
Thanks again [NAME].
Very well served!

I'm writing to express my outmost disappointment in part of the staff of the Welbee's store in St. [NAME]'s.
The story is from a few minutes ago when I entered the store, as I usually do, right before work.
I entered wearing headphones (again - as I always do) and suddenly I do see the entire store staring at me.
I turn around and see the security (the morning shift on the [PHONE]) walking towards me, clapping and calling my [NAME] as if I'm [NAME] type of a dog.
I take off my headphones and ask if I can help with anything, to which he responds saying that I must leave my bag in the lockers.

Mind you I do enter the store with a bag on an almost daily basis and I do not believe I should leave my bag in the lockers (that often give off errors or are broken), keeping in mind that it contains my work laptop and I am responsible for it outside of my work location.
I proceed explaining all that to him, as well as the fact that I do enter the store every [SURNAME] with a bag and he proceeds to insists on me leaving it.
After a brief argument and me letting him know I shall not leave my bag, I am told that I can keep it but I [NAME] have to show its contents upon leaving the store.

Although I do believe that this insinuates the fact that I am stealing, which is neither within my culture nor my education, or is complicit to the way I was raised, I agree as I know that I have not, nor am I going to, do anything wrong.
I proceed with looking for what I went in for, when another employee (usually standing up right next to the cash registers behind a desk) walks towards me and also insists on me leaving my bag.
I explain to him that I do come into the store every [SURNAME] with a bag and somehow this is the first time that I've been stopped.
I also let him know that there are cameras in the store and they can check the fact that I am always wearing a bag in the morning.
I do also point out a few ladies that are wearing bags, to which he responds telling me that mine is a backpack, while theirs is a laptop briefcase.
I then proceed to leave the store as I see no point in continuing to argue with them as they kept on repeating and not even listening to what I'm trying to say.
I do find the attitude towards customers absolutely atrocious starting from the clapping and yelling, to implications of me stealing, to the absolute invasion of privacy and personal space.

BOV Sliema Preluna, today you really and truly failed to provide a satisfactory service... and this is not a first either, but today topped them all!!

The majority of times that we need to use Sliema Preluna branch, other than the fact of excessive [SURNAME] time and not enough chairs... we end up either having 'half' a solution or being 'half' served!
Today we walked in with just 1 client in line, (we had to [SURNAME] a few minutes to get in to the branch as the security officer had gone to get a glass of water from upstairs).

Ms [NAME] didn't know how to solve the issue either, so she asked us to [SURNAME] while she went upstairs to ask someone else for a solution... we waited a good 10 minutes, while [NAME] went upstairs.

I strongly urge all restaurants that offer delivery to adopt a policy of sealing their boxes securely or at the very least, enclosing them in a tamper-proof plastic bag.
This is just a suggestion; it is essential for ensuring accountability.
If a courier were to mishandle our food, it should be immediately obvious due to a torn seal.
Implementing this standard is crucial for maintaining trust and safeguarding the customer experience.

The developer of the site next to us is excavating right next to our wall, not observing [SURNAME] of the 76cm distance required by [SURNAME].

The BCA washed their hands by saying they won't get involved because this is a civil matter that we [NAME] need to handle through the courts, despite that the method statement (and the Civil Code) requires the developer to observe this 76cm distance.
The developer has already hit our corridor wall through carelessness during demolition, displacing a brick (which he verbally promised to repair later).
If something similar happens at the basement levels, it could cause the whole building to collapse.
We had informed the developer through a representation that we do not waiver our right to this 76cm distance.

Our lawyer told us we need to file an injunction with the court to stop the excavation, but warned that the developer would likely retaliate by countersuing us for stopping works, exposing us to financial risk.
Even if we [NAME] the subsequent court case, we would only be awarded damages of around ‚Ç¨10-20,000 which would need to be shared or prorated between all neighbours in the apartment complex.
Our portion would likely be less than ‚Ç¨2,000, which wouldn't even cover the income we'd lose from work and other expenses to pursue this case.

Developers know they are operating with impunity, because the legislative, enforcement, and judicial systems are rigged in their favour, and there is nothing we neighbours can do to protect our rights and our safety.
------------- Update: I would like to thank everyone who provided helpful advice.
I'm going to address [NAME] common points and misconceptions (paraphrased): "The 76cm distance doesn't apply because the developer is removing loose material, not rock cutting.
" - That is not correct.
Apart from the soil and rubble, the developer is also removing their foundations that are situated right next to our wall.

The Avoidance of Damage to Third Party Property Regulations defines excavation as "the cutting or removal of rock, clay and [SURNAME] other natural or human placed material, that forms part of the land, or the removal of [SURNAME] consolidated material".
The foundations and rubble both qualify as "human placed material".
Both the BCA and our lawyer have confirmed that the 76cm distance still applies in this case.
We might have refrained from objecting if the developer was really just removing loose material and keeping the foundations in place, but they are clearly removing the foundations too.
"The developer is removing material thrown there by your own developer.
" - That is not the case.
There was a building on this site (now demolished) that existed [SURNAME] before our apartment block was built.
"The 76cm distance doesn't apply because your block has a basement wall there, not bedrock.
" - That is also not correct.
The 76cm distance applies from the surface level, not from the base of the third-party wall.
Both the BCA and our lawyer have confirmed this.
"Your developer didn't respect the 76cm distance either.
" - The former building on this site was uninhabited when our block was built, so there was no safety risk.
But that's beside the point.
We did not gain anything from it if our developer also excavated illegally.
We paid the full [SURNAME] for our apartment on the assumption that it was constructed legally.
And even if it wasn't, one illegality doesn't justify another.
"Damage [NAME] be covered by the developer's insurance.
" - Insurance does not cover damage if the developer is found to have been breaking the [SURNAME], which is the case here.
"It is safer to proceed this way than to build over the old foundations.
" - That [NAME] or [NAME] not be the case.
We would have been ready to talk with the developer, with the guidance of our architect, if he had approached us about it.
However, the developer deceitfully stated they would respect the 76cm distance in the method statement, so we never got the chance to evaluate whether not doing so is safe or not.
"You are making mountains out of molehills.
" - The developer has already hit our corridor wall with heavy machinery through carelessness.
You can imagine what [NAME] happen if there is similar carelessness applied when excavating right next to our block's basement wall.
"You [NAME]'t know what you're talking about.
" - My position has been corroborated by my lawyer and the BCA, who have seen the same photos that I've posted above (and others).

I appreciate that [NAME] commenters are expressing their disagreement with the definition of "excavation" in good [NAME], but I can see that others are coming from developers or their associates, who have a vested interest in sowing confusion and discrediting posts like this one.
Anyone can verify the [SURNAME] for themselves: [URL] "Call 138.

That number goes to the BCA, who told us they won't intervene because it's a civil matter.
"Talk to a lawyer.
" - We did.
He was ready to file an injunction on our behalf, but we concluded we would be worse off, for several reasons.
We are currently living in a rented apartment since we [NAME]'t feel safe staying next to this construction site.

Feeling peckish or downright hungry?
A fan of Turkish food?
Then look no further than Alem Turkish.
A newly-opened, family-run business which serves, hand on heart, the best turkish food I ever tried.
Everything is made fresh daily (including the bread!
) by the owners themselves!
The mixed grill (for 2) was enormous yet disappeared very quickly thanks to yours truly.
The pide (boat-shaped pizza) was also gargantuan and delicious according to my 9-year old little big champ.
We also sampled baklava which was utterly delicious, devoid of excessive honey and not too sweet; with the right balance of filo and pistachios.
I must also stress that prices are very competitive and far from typical of such an elite area.
Highly recommended!
